expanded_description: Multiplying a binomial by a trinomial requires careful application of the distributive property. Each term of the binomial must be multiplied by each term of the trinomial, resulting in six products that are then combined by adding like terms. This operation builds on the skills developed in multiplying binomials and prepares students for polynomial long division and factoring.

core_concept.principle: To multiply a binomial by a trinomial, use the distributive property: $(a + b)(c + d + e) = a(c + d + e) + b(c + d + e) = ac + ad + ae + bc + bd + be$. Then combine like terms. The result is typically a polynomial with up to four terms after simplification.
core_concept.explanation: Think of this as a handshake between two groups—one group has two people, the other has three. Every person from the first group must shake hands with every person from the second group, giving six handshakes. Then you group together people with the same name (like terms) to count how many of each type you have.

image.alt: Visual representation of binomial times trinomial showing six products
image.caption: Figure 10.5.1: Multiplying a binomial by a trinomial yields six products.

sections.introduction: The most reliable method is to apply the distributive property step by step.

key_concept.definition: To multiply $(a + b)(c + d + e)$, distribute the binomial over the trinomial: first multiply $a$ by each term of the trinomial, then multiply $b$ by each term of the trinomial. This gives $ac + ad + ae + bc + bd + be$. Then combine like terms.
key_concept.context: This method works for any size polynomials—the principle remains the same.

worked_examples.title: Using the Distributive Property
worked_examples.problem:
Multiply using the distributive property:
a) $(x + 3)(x^2 + 2x + 5)$
b) $(2x - 1)(x^2 - 3x + 4)$
c) $(3x + 2)(2x^2 - x - 3)$
worked_examples.concept_applied: Distribute each term of the binomial to every term of the trinomial.

sections.introduction: The vertical method organizes multiplication like multi-digit number multiplication, helping to align like terms.

introduction_image.alt: Vertical multiplication of binomial by trinomial
introduction_image.caption: Figure 10.5.6: The vertical method.

key_concept.definition: Write the trinomial on top and the binomial below, similar to multi-digit multiplication. Multiply the binomial by each term of the trinomial, writing each partial product below, aligning like terms. Then add the partial products.
key_concept.context: This method helps keep terms organized and reduces the chance of missing terms.

worked_examples.title: Using the Vertical Method

image.caption: Figure 10.5.8: Find each product using the vertical method.

worked_examples.problem:
Use the vertical method to multiply:
a) $(x + 2)(x^2 + 3x + 4)$
b) $(2x - 3)(x^2 - 2x + 5)$

step_by_step.calculation: Write as second row, aligning like terms

worked_examples.concept_applied: The vertical method organizes work and helps align like terms.

sections.section_title: 10.5.3 The Area Model (Box Method) for Binomial × Trinomial
sections.introduction: The area model extends naturally to binomial × trinomial using a 2×3 grid.

key_concept.definition: Draw a 2×3 grid. Label the rows with the terms of the binomial and the columns with the terms of the trinomial. Multiply to fill each cell. The sum of all six cells is the product.
key_concept.context: This visual method helps ensure that every combination is included and makes combining like terms easier.

worked_examples.title: Using the Area Model

image.caption: Figure 10.5.12: Use the area model to find each product.

worked_examples.problem:
Use the area model to multiply:
a) $(x + 3)(x^2 + 2x + 1)$
b) $(2x - 1)(x^2 - 3x + 2)$
worked_examples.concept_applied: The area model organizes all six products and makes combining like terms systematic.

image.alt: Summary of area model for binomial × trinomial
image.caption: Figure 10.5.15: Area model summary.

sections.section_title: 10.5.4 Combining Like Terms in the Result
sections.introduction: After multiplying, the six terms often combine into a polynomial with fewer terms.

key_concept.definition: After obtaining the six products, identify terms with the same variable part (same variables raised to the same powers). Add their coefficients to simplify. The result is typically a polynomial of degree one more than the original trinomial's degree (if the binomial is linear).
key_concept.context: This step is crucial—failing to combine like terms leaves the answer unsimplified.

worked_examples.title: Identifying and Combining Like Terms
worked_examples.problem:
Multiply and simplify by combining like terms:
a) $(2x + 3)(x^2 + 4x - 1)$
b) $(3x - 2)(2x^2 - 3x + 5)$
c) $(x + 4)(x^2 - 2x + 3) + (2x - 1)(x^2 + x - 2)$
worked_examples.concept_applied: Always combine like terms after distributing.

sections.section_title: 10.5.5 Multiplying Binomial by Trinomial with Multiple Variables
sections.introduction: The same principles apply when polynomials have more than one variable.

key_concept.definition: When multiplying polynomials with multiple variables, each term in the product will have variables from both factors. Like terms must have exactly the same combination of variables with the same exponents. For example, $xy^2$ and $x^2y$ are not like terms.
key_concept.context: These products appear in geometry and physics applications.

worked_examples.title: Multiplying with Multiple Variables
worked_examples.problem:
Multiply and simplify:
a) $(x + 2y)(x^2 + xy + y^2)$
b) $(2a - b)(a^2 - 2ab + b^2)$
c) $(3x + y)(2x^2 - xy + 3y^2)$
worked_examples.concept_applied: Keep track of all variables; combine only terms with identical variable parts.

sections.introduction: Polynomial multiplication appears in geometry when finding areas and volumes of shapes with variable dimensions.

key_concept.definition: The volume of a rectangular prism is length × width × height. If these dimensions are polynomials, multiplying them may involve binomial × trinomial (or larger) products. Similarly, area of composite shapes may require polynomial multiplication.
key_concept.context: These applications show how polynomial multiplication is used in practical geometry problems.

worked_examples.title: Finding Volume
worked_examples.problem: A rectangular prism has length $(x + 3)$ cm, width $(x - 1)$ cm, and height $(x + 2)$ cm. Find its volume as a polynomial in standard form.
worked_examples.concept_applied: Volume requires multiplying three dimensions—often involves binomial × binomial × binomial.

worked_examples.title: Finding Area of a Composite Shape
worked_examples.problem: A rectangle has length $(2x + 3)$ and width $(x + 4)$. A smaller rectangle of length $(x + 1)$ and width $(x - 2)$ is cut out. Find the area of the remaining region as a polynomial.
worked_examples.concept_applied: Composite shapes involve adding and subtracting polynomial areas.

sections.section_title: 10.5.7 Common Errors and How to Avoid Them
sections.introduction: Students often make specific mistakes when multiplying binomials by trinomials. Awareness helps prevent these errors.

classifications.value: Forgetting to multiply the binomial by every term of the trinomial.
characteristics: Only getting 4 or 5 products instead of 6
Skipping the last term of the trinomial

classifications.value: Incorrect signs when multiplying by a negative term in the binomial.
Adding terms that don't have the same variable part.

worked_examples.problem: A student multiplied $(2x - 1)(x^2 - 3x + 4)$ and got $2x^3 - 7x^2 + 11x - 4$. Is this correct?

step_by_step.explanation: Student's answer matches the correct calculation

sections.introduction: Apply your skills to multiply a variety of binomials by trinomials.

worked_examples.title: Mixed Practice Set
worked_examples.problem:
Multiply and simplify:
1) $(x + 2)(x^2 + 3x + 1)$
2) $(2x - 3)(x^2 - 4x + 5)$
3) $(3x + 1)(2x^2 - x - 2)$
4) $(4x - 2)(x^2 + 2x - 3)$
5) $(x + 3y)(x^2 - 2xy + y^2)$
6) $(2a - b)(a^2 + 3ab - 2b^2)$
7) Find the volume of a box with dimensions $(x+2)$, $(x-1)$, and $(x+3)$.
worked_examples.concept_applied: Practice multiplying various binomials by trinomials.

summary: Multiplying a binomial by a trinomial requires distributing each term of the binomial to every term of the trinomial, resulting in six products. These products are then combined by adding like terms. The distributive property is the fundamental approach, while the vertical method and area model (2×3 grid) help organize the work and prevent missing terms. After multiplication, always combine like terms to simplify the result. When working with multiple variables, like terms must have identical variable parts. Real-world applications include finding volumes of rectangular prisms and areas of composite shapes. Common errors include missing terms, sign mistakes, and combining unlike terms. Mastering this skill prepares students for more advanced polynomial operations, including polynomial long division and working with polynomial functions of higher degree.
